faculty.address:
Tartu linn, 
Tartu linn, Tartumaa 
EST

description.en: The aim of this course is to elucidate fundamental mechanisms of physiology in invertebrates as well as vertebrates and introduce specific adaptations (types of locomotions, camouflage, feeding techniques, deep diving, poisons and venoms etc) of animals living in different environments. The students participate in  practical works to have a closer look at physiological methods in measuring stress in vertebrates and immunity in insects.
description.et: Õpitakse tundma selgrootute ja selgroogsete loomade fundamentaalseid füsioloogilisi mehhanisme ja spetsiifilisi kohastumisi (liikumisviisid, varjevärvus, toitumistehnikad, süvasukeldumine, mürkide toimemehhanismid, ekstreemsete tingimuste talumine jne) erinevatele keskkonnatingimustele. Praktikumides tutvutakse lähemalt füsioloogiliste meetoditega stressi ja immuunsüsteemi mõõtmisel.

objectives.en: The aim of this course is to elucidate fundamental mechanisms of physiology in invertebrates as well as vertebrates and introduce specific adaptations (types of locomotions, camouflage, feeding techniques, deep diving, poisons and venoms etc) of animals living in different environments. The students participate in  practical works to have a closer look at physiological methods in measuring stress in vertebrates and immunity in insects.
objectives.et: Õpitakse tundma selgrootute ja selgroogsete loomade fundamentaalseid füsioloogilisi mehhanisme ja spetsiifilisi kohastumisi (liikumisviisid, varjevärvus, toitumistehnikad, süvasukeldumine, mürkide toimemehhanismid, ekstreemsete tingimuste talumine jne) erinevatele keskkonnatingimustele. Praktikumides tutvutakse lähemalt füsioloogiliste meetoditega stressi ja immuunsüsteemi mõõtmisel.

learning_outcomes.en: 1. Students can describe fundamental mechanisms of physiology in invertebrates and vertebrates.
learning_outcomes.et: 1. Üliõpilased oskavad kirjeldada fundamentaalseid füsioloogilisi mehhanisme selgrootute ja selgroogsete näitel

learning_outcomes.en: 2. Students have a closer look at physiological methods in measuring stress in vertebrates and immunity in insects
learning_outcomes.et: 2. Praktiliste tööde käigus tutvutakse lähemalt kaasaegsete füsioloogiliste meetoditega

learning_outcomes.en: 3. Students can explain specific physiological, anatomical and behavioral adaptations of animals living in different environments.
learning_outcomes.et: 3. Osatakse seletada erinevate organismide spetsiifilisi füsioloogilisi, anatoomilisi ja käitumuslikke kohastumusi eluks erinevates keskkonnatingimustes

description.et: Eristav hindamine

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)

resources.recommended_materials: Willmer, Pat , Stone, G., Johnston, Ian A; Environmental physiology of animals; 2nd ed; Blackwell Pub, 2005.

name.en: Institute of Molecular and Cell Biology

structural_unit.address:
Riia 23, 23b - 134
51010 Tartu linn, 
Tartu linn, Tartumaa 
EST

description.et:
Introduction: adaptation, the maintenance of metabolic equilibrium.
Nerves systems and specific senses in different taxa (V. Tilgar)
Hormones, physiological mechanisms of acute and chronic stress responses in different taxa, neuroendocrinology of behaviour (V. Tilgar)
Chemical communication (pheromones), bioluminescence (R. Kreitsberg)
independent group work
independent group work
Group work and presentations (V. Tilgar)
Physiological genomics (R. Meitern)
Aging and terminal investment (J. Javoish)
Biochemistry of mitochondrial energy production and its relation to animal physiology, behaviour and evolution (K. Kipper)
Immune system and physiological trade-offs in invertebrates (I. Krams)
Measuring immune response in beetles (I. Krams)
Measuring cortisol levels from human saliva (Vanemuise 21, V. Tilgar)
Feeding techniques in different taxa (R. Kreitsberg)
Echolocation, sensing of electric fields, electric organs, adhesive toe pads, adaptations to increased pressure (R. Kreitsberg)
Animal camouflage and physiological mechanisms, adaptations for rapid locomotion (swimming, running, flying) (V. Tilgar)
Poisons and venoms: effects and resistance to venoms (V. Tilgar)
Adaptations of insects to extreme conditions (T. Esperk)
Human impacts on animal populations - physiological mechanisms of detrimental effects (V. Tilgar)
